(G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14).proposition: COMPLAINT FOR BREACH OF COVENANT OF QUIET ENJOYMENT  (G.L. c. 186, § 14)

G.L. c. 186..proposition: Defendant Emily Johnson is an individual, on information and belief residing in Massachusetts, who is the owner and/or lessor of the residential premises located at 24 Chelsea Street, Chelsea, Massachusetts 02150 (the “Premises”), and at all relevant times has acted as Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19, 19A, and 2.proposition: This action is brought in the Chelsea District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19, 19A, and 21, which confer jurisdiction on the District Court over civil actions in which the damages do not exceed the statutory limits.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2..proposition: Venue is proper in this Court because the Premises that are the subject of this action are located in Chelsea, Suffolk County, Massachusetts, and the cause of action arose within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction. See G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 15F.proposition: Defendant, as landlord, is responsible for maintaining the common areas of the building, including the main entry door and its lock, in a condition that is safe and compliant with applicable law.

G.L. c. 143.proposition: Defendant, as landlord, is responsible for maintaining the common areas of the building, including the main entry door and its lock, in a condition that is safe and compliant with applicable law.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: Defendant, as landlord, is responsible for maintaining the common areas of the building, including the main entry door and its lock, in a condition that is safe and compliant with applicable law.

105 C.M.R. 410.750\u2013410.754 (minimum.raw_text: 105 C.M.R. 410.750–410.754 (minimum standards of fitness for human habitation and safe egress/common areas).
105 C.M.R. 410.750\u2013410.754 (minimum.proposition: Defendant, as landlord, is responsible for maintaining the common areas of the building, including the main entry door and its lock, in a condition that is safe and compliant with applicable law.

General Laws c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: General Laws c. 186, § 14 provides in relevant part that a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant,” and that any landlord who does so “shall be liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, and the costs of the action, including a reasonable attorney’s fee.”

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7\u00a7 14, 15F.proposition: The duty to maintain common areas in a reasonably safe condition is part of the landlord’s obligations under Massachusetts law, and failure to maintain such areas can constitute an interference with quiet enjoyment. See *Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443, 451–52 (1979); *Banaghan v. Dewey*, 340 Mass. 73, 80–81 (1959); see also G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 15F; 105 C.M.R. 410.750–410.754.

Williams v. Seder, 306 Mass. 134 (1940).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in residential tenancies and prohibits a landlord from substantially interfering with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Williams v. Seder, 306 Mass. 134 (1940).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a commercial tenancy at will and addresses only whether a landlord’s unilateral notice of increased rent creates a new tenancy without the tenant’s assent. It does not discuss the covenant of quiet enjoyment—express or implied—nor any rule about substantial interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of premises, residential or otherwise. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition stated.
Williams v. Seder, 306 Mass. 134 (1940).relevant_excerpt: "A tenancy at will arises out of an agreement, express or implied, by which one uses and occupies the premises of another for a consideration — usually the payment of rent. The relation between the tenant and the landlord is contractual. Central Mills Co. v. Hart, 124 Mass. 123. Porter v. Hubbard, 134 Mass. 233. Lindsey v. Leighton, 150 Mass. 285. Crowe v. Bixby, 237 Mass. 249."

Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.raw_text: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124 (1959)
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in residential tenancies and prohibits a landlord from substantially interfering with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.case_name: Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment and holds that a landlord’s failure to provide essential services can breach that covenant and amount to constructive eviction. However, the case involves a commercial tenant (a printing business on the fifth floor), not a residential tenancy, and the court does not state that the covenant is implied in residential leases in particular. Thus, while it supports the general rule that substantial landlord interference violates quiet enjoyment, it does not specifically address or establish the proposition as to residential tenancies.
Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Cor.relevant_excerpt: “Failure to furnish such services, at least if serious in extent and not excusable, deprives the lessee of a vital part of what the landlord knows the lessee must have in order to carry on his business. Such a failure constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… and enables the lessee to recover the damages caused to him thereby and also provides the lessee with the defense of ‘constructive eviction’ (if he removes from the premises).”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in residential tenancies and prohibits a landlord from substantially interfering with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes G.L. c. 186, § 14 as codifying the tenant’s common-law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, thereby confirming that such a covenant is implied in Massachusetts tenancies. It also characterizes § 14 as prohibiting landlords from interfering—through at least negligent conduct—with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises, which necessarily means substantial interference with use and enjoyment. Thus the case supports the stated proposition, even though its main issue is the fault standard and interaction with the lead paint statute.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). At common law, and as originally enacted by statute, the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibited a landlord from wilful or intentional interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises. In 1973, the statute was rewritten… [L]andlords could now be held liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.raw_text: Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976 (1985)
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in residential tenancies and prohibits a landlord from substantially interfering with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.support_reasoning: The excerpt shows that the tenant asserted a counterclaim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and that the trial judge found a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, but the Appeals Court opinion as quoted does not discuss the nature or scope of that covenant. There is no explicit statement that a covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in residential tenancies or that it prohibits substantial interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment; the focus is on c. 93A damages and treble damages. Thus the case, at least in the provided text, does not clearly establish the proposition for which it is cited.
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. 976.relevant_excerpt: “On October 23, 1981, LeClair sent Brown a ‘demand letter’ seeking damages and requesting relief (repairs) under c. 93A for problems relating to leaks, the January 31, 1980, flood, cockroaches, the assault, and breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Brown’s agent responded by denying *980 any unfair practice, claiming that the problems had been corrected and refusing to make repairs as they had been ‘made long ago.’”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in residential tenancies and prohibits a landlord from substantially interfering with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that “every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant” of quiet enjoyment and describes that right as freedom from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the leased premises. It then applies both the common-law covenant and G.L. c. 186, § 14 to a residential tenancy, holding the landlord liable where repeated flooding interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. This directly supports that Massachusetts law implies such a covenant in residential tenancies and that it prohibits substantial interference with use and enjoyment.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. at 102\u2013.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 is violated when the landlord, or someone for whose conduct the landlord is responsible, engages in acts or omissions that cause a serious and substantial interference with the tenant’s use of the premises, including failure to remedy conditions that threaten the tenant’s safety or security. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 102–04; *Al-Ziab*, 424 Mass. at 850–52.

Al-Ziab, 424 Mass. at 850\u201352.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 is violated when the landlord, or someone for whose conduct the landlord is responsible, engages in acts or omissions that cause a serious and substantial interference with the tenant’s use of the premises, including failure to remedy conditions that threaten the tenant’s safety or security. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 102–04; *Al-Ziab*, 424 Mass. at 850–52.

Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443, 451.proposition: The duty to maintain common areas in a reasonably safe condition is part of the landlord’s obligations under Massachusetts law, and failure to maintain such areas can constitute an interference with quiet enjoyment. See *Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443, 451–52 (1979); *Banaghan v. Dewey*, 340 Mass. 73, 80–81 (1959); see also G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 15F; 105 C.M.R. 410.750–410.754.
Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443, 451.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that a landlord has a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep common areas (and any area in the landlord’s control) safe, and that violations of building and sanitary codes are evidence of negligence. However, Crowell is a personal injury negligence/warranty case; it does not discuss statutory "quiet enjoyment" under G.L. c. 186, § 14 or characterize failure to maintain common areas as an interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus it supports the duty-to-maintain-safety aspect, but not the quiet-enjoyment component of the claimed proposition.
Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443, 451.relevant_excerpt: "In those cases we held that a landlord has a general obligation to exercise reasonable care in keeping safe the common areas of an apartment building or similar structure for use by his tenants and their visitors, and that the duty is not defined by the safety conditions that existed at the commencement of the tenancy. We also held that violation of a statute or building code provision related to safety was evidence of the landlord’s negligence." (377 Mass. at 447)

Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73, 80\u201.proposition: The duty to maintain common areas in a reasonably safe condition is part of the landlord’s obligations under Massachusetts law, and failure to maintain such areas can constitute an interference with quiet enjoyment. See *Crowell v. McCaffrey*, 377 Mass. 443, 451–52 (1979); *Banaghan v. Dewey*, 340 Mass. 73, 80–81 (1959); see also G.L. c. 186, §§ 14, 15F; 105 C.M.R. 410.750–410.754.
Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73, 80\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes a landlord’s duty, under Massachusetts law, to use reasonable care to keep common passageways (including an elevator serving tenants) in safe condition and holds the owners liable when the elevator, a common facility, was negligently maintained. However, the case is framed as a negligence action and does not discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14 or the doctrine of interference with quiet enjoyment, so it supports only the first part of the proposition (duty to maintain common areas in reasonably safe condition), not the specific ‘quiet enjoyment’ consequence. The citation is therefore accurate for the duty principle but not as direct authority for the quiet-enjoyment aspect.
Banaghan v. Dewey, 340 Mass. 73, 80\u201.relevant_excerpt: “It is well settled that a landlord need only use reasonable care to keep his common passageways in as good a condition as they were or appeared to be at the time of the letting. … Here the faulty governor and disconnected interlocks were defects not apparent to the tenants, and the fact, if it was a fact, that they were in the same inoperative condition at the time of the letting as they were when the accident occurred does not relieve the trustees of liability.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: The implied warranty of habitability, recognized in *Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973), and codified in part in G.L. c. 111, § 127A and the State Sanitary Code, reinforces the requirement that landlords maintain residential premises, including common areas, in a condition fit for human habitation and reasonably secure against foreseeable harms.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a concurrence/dissent, not the majority, but it accurately reflects that the court was recognizing a change from caveat emptor toward an implied obligation tied to habitability standards. Justice Quirico expressly accepts that, for dwelling units, landlords have an implied obligation—grounded in G.L. c. 111, § 127A and the State Sanitary Code—to meet minimum fitness-for-human-habitation standards, and that this obligation is interdependent with the tenant’s rent obligation. While he criticizes the majority’s broader, less code‑tethered ‘warranty of habitability,’ his reasoning still supports the proposition that the case (and the statutory/code scheme it relies on) reinforces landlords’ duties to maintain residential premises, including common areas, in a condition fit for human habitation and reasonably secure against foreseeable harms.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… It expressly provides that ‘[n]o person shall … let to another for occupancy any dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit… which does not comply’ with its provisions, and further provides a criminal penalty for violation of its provisions. It expressly places the burden on the owner to comply with the prescribed minimum physical standards for rented dwelling units… [T]he various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards…”}

Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. at 9.raw_text: Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. at 977–78
Brown v. LeClair, 20 Mass. App. Ct. at 9.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that disturbances affecting the safety, health, or security of tenants—such as persistent unsafe or unsanitary conditions, or the landlord’s failure to address them after notice—can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. at 102–04 (sewage backups and landlord’s failure to correct them); *Al-Ziab*, 424 Mass. at 850–52 (unsafe conditions and landlord’s neglect); *Brown v. LeClair*, 20 Mass. App. Ct. at 977–78.
